Message.Text: You know I'm not usually into that kind of crap, but I gave you a shoutout.
Oh?
In Rhubarb, entitled "Better late than never" or something to that effect.
On the way
I'm still not sure I like the idea of a PC thread. Seems self righteous, pompous and spammy to me.
I think I'll let you off on one of 5000
:P
Cheers for the shout out tho
I've been lurking the forums lately
last few weeks of uni, free time is podcasts and gaming
Not a hell of a lot to say
I did however get fable 2, pretty cool
PC or CoffeeMachine360?
being the only platform it's on
Ah, fair enough.
Atleast currently
I probably should have known that... :S
When it comes to PC I'll play it./
I'm sure in a year, Fable 2: Finished Product will be released like last time
I noticed pooman around the forums also
ain't seen his pretty face about in a while
Yeah, I saw him too. Can't say I know him though. I mean, I know his name and his avatar, that's 'bout it.
He was a bit of a tool in all the socials
Always re-defining the word "friendly fire" and such
Ah.
Is this who I think it is?
It's Bomer?
Ah hoi hoi
Hi there
You asked the other day
dickyBoy said: Ah. Is this who I think it is?
Yeah, I can see who you are on this machine.
On the other one it just lists your email address though. As if I remember who they belong to... :-)
Ah right, it's bomer from PCPP btw
I got a new email a lil while back
I know it's you.
I felt like chatting about something... maybe something you'd said on the forums. Can't remember what now, though.
No worries
I haven't been posting a lot
But it's good stuff when you do.
Although, I do have stupid amounts of free time at the moment
I still read regularly though
Oh? You should make a game then. ;-)
haha, I should indeed
Maybe after christmas
I got a flash artist friend to work with
Why wait? :P
Flash?!?
Yeup
<Rewinds> Flash?!?
<Fast Forwards> Yeup
Oh, you're good. :-)
lol
So why the attraction to Flash? Unless you just meant they're a vector artist (I'd like one of those...)
Haha, yeh, well I've dabbled in it, and it seems a pretty quick way to get stuff done and easy to get a release out that everyone can play
Yeah, true points.
My mate uses flash for cartoons and animations and stuff, just his preffered tools to work with
For a cartoon style game it could work well, actually.
It's not like you'd need the performance for anything crazy.
And, indeed, according to Mike McShaffry, "getting released is a feature all games need", so if the tools get the job done then they're good enough.
(I still think you should make a *real* game though. :P)
I like your use of the word *real*
hehe
Although, look at the affect Desktop Tower Defence had
I suggest starting with something small, regardless of the platform.
There's been atleast half a dozen games since that have come out based on the popularity of that game
Aye, something exactly like Tower Defence
And the funny thing is that so many of them are crud. I mean, the gameplay is decent enough mechanically, but PJ Monsters is the only one I've played that's actually *fun* to play.
I had already played the genre to death in warcraft 3
I think a lot of the maps made for that are better than many of the actual release to follow it
I've only played one.

You raise a good point, though. The reason, I think, is that community mappers generally couldn't care less about looks because they can't change them anyway, so they focus on just getting gameplay right.

Plus, in war3, it was all multiplayer. Versus, solo or team, either way you atleast had someone to compete against, even if it was directly, or in a friendly competitive team way or just chatting and watching what your mates are doing. That's sorta been lost
Ahhh, I never thought of that.
So what code wizardry have your studies enlightened you upon?
Oh God, that's a lame sentence. Forgive me, hectic week.
Uhhh, first year stuff? :)
its 1am
Judge not
That too.
Did they start you with Java, C++, or some "learner" language?
Sweet. You quite possibly know more about it than I do then.
I also did a "creative" programming course last term in Processing, like a java based drawing language
So they taught you to program creatively?
In first year?
So they can subsequently bash it out of you over the next two?
Lol, barely
It's basically a programming course run by the creative arts subject
Oh, I see.
So was there anything creative about it?
Or was it more "programming for artists"?
Well you where supposed to "create" something
yeh basically
Cool...
Had a major work to create something arty
So (how) was it different to "programming for geeks"?
Uh,, There was a girl in one of our labs?
I ask, because it's my task to teach our lead artists some form of programming.
A what?!? A "girl"? I've heard of those...
They're like "men", but pretty lookin' and sweet, right?
Something to that affect
So how well do you understand pointers, refs and values?
Pointers I got
*thumbs up*
Values you also get, you just don't usually call them anything.
Uhm, sorta stopped at that, implementation of pointers in hash tables and linked lists and what not was the last 3 weeks or so of this terms course
References are essentially alternate variables that point at the same data.
Which seems like a really pointless thing to do to begin with, I know.
Ah ok, I think we've played with the concept, but again not refered to as that
Like as a method of searching, we'd have an array and an array of pointers to the data, and instead of sorting the data itself, we'd sort the array of pointers... That sort of thing?
Well when you start actually using them they'll be called that. In C++, if you're using a & when declaring function arguments then that's what you're using.
Not quite, that's different again. That's indirection using pointers, which you do to save the overhead of actually moving data

The idea of a reference is that you can allow something out of scoe to access data as though it were local without opening your scope. If that doesn't make sense, don't worry. It won't until you need to do it, and then when you've done it a few times it'll seem easy.
So have they got you to write anything cool for assignments?
Uh, not really
We got to stitch together some image files
That's semi cool.
Did you get to stitch them together over a mesh of triangles? That'd be cooler.
Haha, no GUI's in first year
THat's not a GUI, it's a 3D model. :P
My coolest assignment was writing a CPU emulator. I've got a feeling I told you about it last time we talked, though.
Yeah, i got that, but it does put limitations on the coolness of projects
Yeah, i think it came up
Ah right, now I get what you meant.
GUIs are a pain in the ass.
Well... that's not exactly true. Most GUI libraries I've used are pains.
On a slightly less geeky topic, played anything particularly good lately?
I finished Link to the Past
Zelda?
On GBA (Ds Lite)
Of course :P
Is that the toon shaded one?
No, SNES
Uhm, Zelda 3?
You don't know your zelda's? :-O :-O
Alas, I wouldn't know Zelda 3 from SSB.
Haha, oh boy, Zelda is a pretty important series to me
The only Zelda I've even played was the one on N64, and that only for 15 minutes.
I suppose Ocarina of Time launched at a good time for me
And I played a lot of LttP as youngster on snes
Never finished it though
Even on the PSP with save states
Bloody hard game
I wish they still made 'em that way...
Either I'm stupidly good, or most new games are stupidly easy.
I really should play a Zelda game properly, though. They're influential to say the least.
I'm not anti-easy
In that, say a game like portal. I invited a mate over and he asked to see it and was able to sit down and finish it in a few hours with relative ease
But I still love accomplishment and a touch of stupidly hard frustrating platforming or whatever
That's a different kind of easy, though.

That's more accessibility, in that the game's challenge came from something that didn't assume fine motor reflexes, familiarity with FPSs, tactical thinking, or anything else "learned". It taught you what you needed to know as you went, and only assumed basic problem solving skills. It was a marvellously well designed game, imo.

I think it might have something to do with 3D. Like most 3d platforming or whatever, if you miss a jump you feel like it's the fault of the game or the camera or what have you. But in Super Mario Bros, it's expected you fail half the jumps. 2D creates direct limitations for the environment you have to play in.
Yes, definitely.
2D is also sometimes easier to understand for users, because abstractions can be more clear.

So, take the new Prince of Persia for example, I hear it's overly easy (haven't played it myself). If you spent the majority of your playthrough in that retrying jumps over and over, how satisfying would it be. I spent literally hours each day training in SMB about 6 months playing it over and over again trying to finish the game (on the Wii Virtual console)
Yeah, that's the exact problem I had with it.
Oh and btw, the wiimote held sideways destroy's your thumb after an hour or so of platforming
No consequence for failure except that in fights it makes them last longer.
It's a real shame, it's the one letdown in an otherwise excellent game.
I'd still rate it highly overall, but if the game were challenging I'd probably not have taken it back to EB on day 6...
Did you play Prey btw?
Yeah, I did.
What about the way that game delt with consequence of death
Prey did a much better job if you ask me.
Sleight of hand, perhaps, but it felt like there was still a consequence because as soon as you died you were thrust into another fight - this time to get your life back.
I never lost that fight, don't know what would have happened if I did.
Yeah, I liked the way they chose to do it.
You can't lose
Thought so.
You just get less health back when you come back in
FIgured it'd work like that.
In PoP it doesn't even break the flow of the game.
But, the idea of saving/reloading is pretty nonesense and usually a good way to remove you from the experience
Like in the Half-Life games, I'd always be quick saving because of the jumping puzzles
Agreed. I'm all for exploring ways not to have the player have to stop playing to win, whch is essentially what relying on loading is doing.

Games *require* some kind of win/lose scenario. Problem is that until recently the assumption has been that win = finishing all levels and lose = death, which really doesn't add up since it's assumed that you will die on your way to winning. So to win you're meant to lose... what?
Haha
Like, shin megami tensei?
Which is..?
I should get a list of games to investigate from you.
Personally I really like games where the win/lose scenario is player driven. Torment seemed to do that pretty well, where death wasn't only not losing but was considered a valid gameplay choice.
I never played it(yet), JRPG thats half school/dating sim and half dungeon crawling demon poessesing madness. But the basic idea of shooting yourself in the head to fight is just wikked
Umm, its Persona
Persona 4 was just released
But to summon demons and such, your characters draws a gun and shoots themselves in the head
I thought that would be like the most bad ass ending to an FPS
Interesting.
lol, what a play on words.
"First person shooter, where not only are you shooting *in* the first person, you actually *shoot the first person* too".
:D
Like, the craziest way to end the half life 3 or whatever, if you as gordon had to commit suicide
Aslong as it wasn't blantantly forshadowed from the get go and used as a cheap gimmick
Agreed.
I'm not a fan of forshadowing.
Particularly in Half-Life where the whole thing is stuck in first person, muteless etc. To have such a dramatic ending would kick ass.
It could be hard to make it dramatic, though.
Or if the Wii Motion sensing actually worked without the motion plus, having to actually draw the gun to your temple and fire...
Without flashing on screen prompts
PoP managed something similar, but it just wasn't dramatic.
Ooh? The new one?
Yeah.
(spoiler free please:P)
Its $50 on PC at EB
Don't worry, I'm being vague to avoid the spoiler.
You should play the game.
or $80, or something, I can't remember
Oh really?
$70 I think
But I have a $20 gift voucher still
$70 sounds right. JB have it for $70, I know that.
Yeah, get it and play it when you can. It's really good.
I think it was $70 and marked off $20 on xmas sales
Wow... EB actually having a good price... whodathunkit!
Lol insane
I might grab it after I budget christmas shopping
I'm thinking of buying it again just because of the DRM thing.
You know ubisoft games, will probably be $20 in 8 months time
Again, the lack of drama in the "rational emotional response" sequence in PoP could have been due to the lack of consequences.
Even if what you were doing ended up being wrong, who cares?
It's not like it'll set you back further than a minute.
Right oh, I might pick it up
anyways, I gotta hit the sack
Fare tired
Fair enough, mee too I guess.
Catchya
I watched all 3 back to the future movies with dad tonight
:F
Yo
Hay Hay
Welcome aboard. :-)
Haha, thank you sir
I'll shoot you over a Torque build so you can have a tinker.
Oh wikked
My license only allows me access to the source, I can't share that. Shouldn't matter though, as I intend for this to be done 100% in script anyway.
Okeydokey
Just having a quick browse of the example builds that come with the SDK.
Ok, just cooking dinner myself
What I'll do, then, is decide which one to send you, stick it on an FTP somewhere and then link you.
Ok, awesome, thanks alot man
You're welcome. Thanks for joining me.
I'll be back in a bit, cooking and eating and watching how I met your mother oh my!
(doesn't exactly roll of the tongue I know)
I'll talk to you in a bit
Oh yeah, go and make a post in that thread when you can saying that you've joined me and we'll be building a prototype together. :-)
http://www.megaupload.com/?d=PLXSP1HC
Cheers
Enter Password?
please42
Oh, you're working with TGEA
Yeah. That an issue?
No, not at all
I just remember following the press releases of TGEA (or TSE or whatever it used to be called) and the tribes tech demo that became legions awfully closely
Their development is a mess.
I wouldn't start any commercial project with Torque. For this kind of thing it'll more than do the job, though.
Im just having a look through some of the script files
Something you need to note with Torque is that it's designed from the ground up as a client-server engine.
Even when you're playing on a single PC the client and server logic are still being run completely seperately.
As you can see looking at the script folders, they're split into two - server and client - based on where they run.
So, that means consistancy is very important between the two?
Yes, it also means that you have to code without assuming that the client side is 100% up to date with the server side and vice versa.
You also need to know what data is stored where so that when you modify it you do so from the right place.
That's not as hard as it may sound, so please don't quit just yet. :-)
Getting the server and client to talk to each other is pretty simple, so what you do is implement all of the game logic in the server half and have it send info updates to the players.
Server side *does*, client side *displays*.
Gotcha
Had to read over a few times but, got it
Datablocks are something else you should take note of.
Have you done any OO programming?
Uh, Open Office programming?
:S
Object Oriented. C++, Java, Python, something like that where you use classes to make objects.
haha, yes
I started on python, and moved to C++ with uni
I have worked with classes yes
but the kind of classes one uses in first year uni mostly...
Ok then, a datablock is kind of *like* a class in that it's used to describe something, rather than be something.
They represent a block of data (funny that, eh?) that's used to initialise an object.
So once it's initialised changing the datablock doesn't change the object.
If you take a look in server/scripts/players/player.cs and go down to line 434 you'll see the datablock that describes the default player object.
The most simple way to look at it is that it stores all of the data about a player that doesn't change.
ok, so its attributes of a player than dont need to change, but need to be kept track of anyway?
I'd be more inclined to say "don't often change and need to be common amongst all instances". So if you make 20 players using that datablock, they will all have the same base data.
oh ok, that makes sense
Underneath that there's a whole lot of PLAYERDATA::onXXX(%this...) functions. They're called from the engine whenever certain events occur.
For instance, PLAYERDATA:: onCollision(%this, %obj, %col) gets called whenever the player object collides with another entity.
Ok, cool
One more thing before I stop breaking your brain for the night, over in server/scripts/game.cs you'll find the functions that make the game actually play.
The function names are more or less self explanitory, and should give you a good idea of what they do or when they get called.
The one thing I can't remember is exactly what the %this variable refers to.
Ahh, found it. It points at the calling object.
I'll have a good look through it
Im going out tommorow, but tommorow evening I'll have a look into it, and from that point I've got epic ammounts of free time
Do you have any suggestions of places i should look
Don't stress too much. It's all daunting when you first look at it.
Well, i'd say start by picking something and trying to make it happen.
Print a message to the console when you run into something saying what object collided with what or something like that.
yeah, I thought I'd give a few things like that a go
Or, for something a bit more visual, make a GUI that shows something and a script that updates it - GPS coordinates or something.
If you're really adventurous you could make a box that you can push around or something, too.
(and not cheat by using a physics object :P)
Haha, wouldn't dare (A)
I'll send you the documentation tomorrow, with a few tutorials.
Thanks a lot
I really appreciate it
No, thank you. :-)
I hope I'm not too much of a burden, this is gonner be a big learning experience also
That's cool. I'm sure you'll do fine. I made my first 3D game in Torque without any help, so I'm sure you'll be fine.
Oh, it wasn't an FPS, either. :S
Oh really? Well done sir :P
*shakes head* I don't think that when I look back on it...
Anyway, I'll leave you in peace.
It'd be nice to have knowledge of how to use an engine like torque at my disposal in the future
Yeah, i gotta go entertain company
My mate and I are giving an Ocarina of time walkthrough over MSN together, haha, so now we have to do something slightly less geeky for a while
thanks a bunch dicky
Umm, and whenever you get a chance to send that documentation and tutorials; thanks in advance! I really appreciate it heaps mate
Go do something with your mate. We'll have plenty of time to talk code while we make cool shit. :-)
Awesome, thanks again
Seeya. I'll send the docs tomorrow. I'd do it now, but it'll take a while to upload.
Bye
No worries, cheers, talk to you later
Woo, docs finally uploaded.
http://www.megaupload.com/?d=Z9BV18YH
Cheers
I was about to ask about it
This is something you'll quickly come to agree sucks about Torque if you work with it for a bit - the docs are incomplete and sometimes out of date.
Oh terrific :)
Luckily, what we want to do should be well enough covered.
I mean, it's pretty basic FPS stuff.
Um, Password?
please42, same as before.
Just got Frontlines: Fuel of War (freebie with something I bought for work) and I'm trying to give it a shot. It requires two 900 meg patches, plus a couple of smaller ones, before I can play. Crazy!
Epic
Thats getting into MMO patching territory
Yeah, been downloading for 45 minutes now and still have ~1.5 gigs to go.
They don't even have a cumulative patch for newcomers to grab it all at once.
Oh mean
I bought age of conan like a week after it came out
and then got to enjoy the 3gb of patches to download
Fuck.
We should make sure our whole game is under 100 megs.
Screw that shit.
That game had a rough launch
So I've heard.
Still, featuring tits was a great way to ensure an immature audience.
And therefore a community with a higher-than-average quantity of lame.
Oh, you have no idea
I had enough of an idea to stay the hell away.
I luckily convinced a mate to buy it with us, so we have a bit of fun griefing
I've gotta say, though, Warhammer seems to have an excellent community.
I've not run into a single "smacktard", ever, which I find amazing.
Shocking :-O
And yes, I played it for more than 30 minutes.
I guess it was targeted at a bit of an older community
Nearly three months, playing a couple of days a week (more when I could).
I got to level 30 in WoW, was enough for me
Oh crap, I just got a msg, "Im outside ur house"
And they are females, so i must venture fourth
Thanks for the documentation though, I'll get stuck into it and let you know how it goes
Don't get too hung up on it. Take a read of the tutes and overviews, but don't worry about "knowing it".

Once you've got a bit familiar with it (ie: after a night or two of actually doing stuff) you'll probably find that the best way to find stuff out is to look at how similar stuff is already being done.
Some cool discussion going on in the mod thread.
Let me know when you've got a bit o' time up your sleeve if you do later on, and we'll do some Torqueing.
I'm thinking a networked test and then implementing one of those features.
Hay, sorry, I did have a plans to see benjamin button, which where cancelled, but now are back on, so not tonight
Probably free from here on out, sounds good though
That's cool.
No rush, I'm not going to force you to code. ;-)
Let me know when you *are* free and we'll plan around that.
The "Beginners blog of torque" from the documentation you gave us was a good read
Well it should be fine from tommorow
Us?
me, myself, I
Shirespeak
Ahh, schizt :P
*schizo
"Chuck us a coke"
It might have been from the torque community site
oh no, it was in "TDN Articles"
Yeah, TDN.
One of the better pieces of documentation for Torque, but sadly only as complete as anything else.
Anyway, I'll let you get to your stuff.
yeh, I gotta scoot
I'll catch you later
oh btw, I scored an Atari 520 st
and a little collection of a few old games, war zone, super breakout, space invaders, falcon (on two 320kb discs!:-O) and old atari arcade stick and a flight stick
Piece of history I tells ya
Wow, that's a piece of gaming history right there.
Snap! ;-)
haha :P
One of the first computers with a GUI and mouse
That wasn't a photocopier. :-)
Hard to game play games on a photocopier (A)
Anyways, I gotta be heading off now
Bye. :-)
Catcha later

Orrite, I did a short burst of surface stuff. Made a basic in-game GUI with a crosshair (read: circle and dot), a health and ammo bars, and health and ammo numbers. Still to go in are: - Score - Ammo timer - Team indicator - Team size indicator? (Not sure if this one is needed. But hey, that's why it's a prototype. :-) We'll just let the mob decide.)
Hay, I just sat down
I also figured out how to make a custom font work. Turns out it's fairly easy. Also turns out one of my old pet-hate bugs is still there, too.
Haha, hi. :-)
(Benjamin Button was quite good)
Cool. The premise is really interesting, I think I'll go see it.
It's a long flick, good 3 hours or so
Wow
I'm still devastated by the end of 1up
The what now?
1up got bought by UGO
I know that. And UGO told people not to come in on Monday?
Midway-Ratbag style?
There seems to be about 10 people left on
but EGM got axed, and nearly all the 1up staff
All the 1up show crew got fired too
But, a bunch of them started doing another podcast straight away
The guy in charge of the 1up Show posted the soundtrack of 40 odd songs they used for the 1up Show
and Im downloading the last episode that I didn't get because I was capped
I invested a lot emotionally in 1up :$
Yeah, that sucks.
Lets go punch Ajy. That'll make you feel better.
:D
Haha
I think I might donate some cash there way
I've spent literally hundreads upon hundreads of hours listening to 1up's podcasts
I owe them atleast a $20
... ... how do you quantify that?!?
Couple bucks is the least I could do?
No no, I didn't mean you personally.
I mean, hundreds of hours for thousands of people, maybe more.
It's more philosophical than a real answerable question. It's also far too late for me to consider academic fluff like this.
Yeah, it's a right shame the awful bloody management at Ziff
Same story just about everywhere. :-(
Ahoy there
You know what one man doesn't need
3 boot managers
*shakes fist at pc*
Three?
three
I've got three.
Well my three don't play nice
They rarely do.
GRUB is always good. The Windows ones not so.
I re-installed vista on a newer hard drive
And the old one was left as the primary
and then I tried the windows 7 beta
Which then broke that drive 8-)
I think I'm going to reformat today
I've been fighting with this for the last year or so
I finally got rid of the old boot manager,
But I've re-organised all my stuff around
Do you have all of your OSes installed on drives that are seperate from where you store your personal/saved data?
And it's been a good 18 months since I've reformatted
Umm, All my games and media on other drives
Only thing with my OS is program data and music
Good, that makes a format fairly easy. :-)
Yeah, I suppose I should move my music around to
I'm just hesitant with Itunes and the weird way vista manages its user data
Don't know about Vista, and I avoid iTunes.
Itunes is the easiest method to support my Podcast addiction
You feel like doing some Torquing later on? Say, 8ish until 10ish?
I'm going to reformat my iPod too, my podcasts menu has turned into a gelatine fueled slugfest of crappy performance
Yeah, sounds good
Surely there's some open source tool you can get that'll perform better, let you do things your way and be less DRM pushy?
It's probably just over fragmented, I download like 15+ podcasts a week
and I delete a bunch every few weeks to manage space
and I haven't restored for a year or two
How 'bout you get a seperate HDD just for your casts, then?
I know that probably sounds overkill, but that's a reasonable amount of data wrangling there.
Not a bad idea, I think the iPod suffers more than my computer drives, hopefully a reformat will speed it up
it takes like a minute to navigate from the top of my list to the middle
Oh, duh, you don't listen to them on your PC. Silly me.
Haha, yeah
It ran fine like ayear ago when I had 30 podcasts being downloaded each week
So I presume wiping it and restoring it should help out
I wanna go play GRID on my big telly.
Need something to attach my wheel to, however... hmm.
Well, I'll be back in a few hours.
Around 8ish.
Sure thing
oh gosh
Copying 99,817 items
Maybe I should just re-installed and delete what I dont need
Wow.
That's crazy.
Vista ETA is 6 hours atm...
Well, if your PC is still out of order tonight we can do the Torqueing another time, so don't stress about that. Good luck with it all.
I should have it worked out by then
Oh and are you using the Torque IDE?
I was just using notepad++
I will be, that's for sure.
But I saw a version of Jedit with a plugin for Torque
Ther'es also Torsion.
Is that not what you are using?
Ok, i gtg
Im gonner close all my programs and delete as much as of my program files as windows will let me :)
I am back from my GRIDding.
Hay
Hi there.
So, it seems that Torsion costs money.
25 day free trial
Should cover it? (Y)
I used CodeWeaver in the past, that was good. Alas, it seems to have disappeared.
Link is there, website is not.
I've got Torsion up and running
Cool.
I will have shortly.
I'll send you an update.
The GUI stuff I've already done.
My suggestion for tonight is that we get a game going over the internet and join it, see what happens and confirm that it actually works.
Then we get one of the features going, I'm thinking the ammo counter.
Ok, sounds good
Err, rather, the ammo timer.
As that involves having data on the server and then keeping all of the clients synched with it.
And the GUI stuff that you've implemented, does that based on the players ammo?
No, it's just a piece of text.
It can be changed, but there's currently no code to change it.
Is that**
So do you already have variables attached to the ammo stocks, or will we have to create that first
We'll have to create those.
Ok, just seeing where we are
Also, have you ever used SVN (Subversion) or anything similar?
Uh, no
Never really had to
I don't have a personal server at the moment, so we can't SVN at the moment, but it might be a good idea later on. We'll see how this goes first, though.
That offering to send you a file?
Yup
It cant be an exe tho
MSN doesn't let you
Gah, lame junk.

See, we need an intermediate "ammo" variable.
Because Jacka's idea is that one common ammo pool is used for everything.
So first we need to represent that pool.

No, just for a player first.
Then once we know how much meta-ammo we have, we use that on a per-gun basis to see how many shots we can fire.
So like a universal ammo pool to operate all your guns?
Exactly.

guiHealthCounter.setText(100 - LocalClientConnection.getControlObject().getDamageLevel());
So, that's going in one of the main program loops?
That's going in one of two places.
First option is wherever the GUI is updated.
Second option is wherever the client's ControlObject (ie: the player) has its damage level updated.
The latter is the better of the two, because there's no need to continually re-calculate the number. Updating it when we know it's changed is good enough.

:P
I mean does it have to be called
Yes, definitely.
That probably doesn't make sense, so I'll break it down.
The function being called is "commandToClient", but you probably noticed that the one we made on the client side was called "clientCmd<stuff>".

It's a scripting thing. The engine knows that when you make a "clientCmd<stuff>" function that it'll get called via a server message, so all the server has to send is the <stuff> part of the name. When the client gets <stuff> it finds the matching clientCmd.

So, back on the server side, the "commandToClient()" function takes three arguments: Firstly is the client the message is being sent to, secondly is the message that's being sent, and thirdly is the argument list for that command.
Ok, that makes sense
Phew.

Put simply, you're not calling the command from the server, you're sending the client a message to call it.
